text.p: These are the stories making headlines in the Namibian newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Ex-Plan fighters in the north are becoming increasingly unhappy with the way the People's Liberation Army of Namibia (Plan) Veterans Trust is being run.
- The legal assistance centre's request to the high court, asking for protection from harassment by the Namibian security forces has been postponed until today.
- The president's decree against public demonstrations without explicit permission of the Namibian police, is being exercised.
- The Namibian justice system is now trying to avoid collapse by introducing a change of law, which is to give magistrate courts greater powers and so improve the efficiency of the judiciary.
- Production from the Kudu gas fields is to become a reality with the first cooperation agreement between South Africa and Namibia soon to be signed.

- Namibia is to take part in Expo '98 in Lisbon, the biggest international fare of the millenium. N$10 million is needed for Namibia to realise its plans of an own pavilion and national day at the Expo.
